body: Is there any progress / activity on this?

May be gradient explosion.
Try to use relu as an activation function or decrease learning rate.
Is there a framework for object detection like SSD available with C++ and Mxnet ?
I will check it later. thanks

@horserma What is your ctx?

```
net.bind(...., # ctx= ??
    group2ctx={'dev1': mx.gpu(0), 'dev2': mx.gpu(1)})
```

I think I'm missing how it's related.  It looks like to me the latest failure was a memory corruption error.
```bash
test_ndarray.test_cached ... *** Error in `/usr/bin/python3': malloc(): smallbin double linked list corrupted: 0x00007fad500008c0 ***
script returned exit code 134
```
No rush to merge this one though.  I'll periodically rebase it until the tests pass.
`mx.sym.BlockGrad` makes the outermost grads zeros and be able to bp without effects. `mx.sym.MakeLoss` makes a node be able to bp too but with loss effects, for example, `mx.sym.MakeLoss(A * B)`.
i know BlockGrad can make BP be without effect, but it can not stop BP.
Then I think you should hack gradient pass in nnvm because this pass ensures that every head bp.
yeah.....
Any update? same error here
@yajiedesign is het possible to integrate cpp package in nightly build release?

Unfortunately the mxnet pyhton on windows through 'pip install -U --pre mxnet' does not run on GPU:
 
C:\projects\mxnet-distro-win\mxnet-build\dmlc-core\include\dmlc/logging.h:308: [16:09:26] C:\projects\mxnet-distro-win\mxnet-build\src\storage\storage.cc:113: Compile with USE_CUDA=1 to enable GPU usage

Is it possible to pip install a version with gpu support?
I install mxnet by **pip install mxnet-cu80** so that I can use GPU.
Thanks, I should have read the thread #7362 better. But yeah, it works now!!! many thanx.
I'll be included in the plan

different versions of CUDA using different DLL names, should not have any impact.
net look like too simple and data too small,CPU copy to GPU time cannot be counteracted.please use big num_inputs and complex net try again.

Change would mean that we will enable lapack when we find the library in /usr/lib64. We have to  guarantee that in these cases, /usr/lib64 will also be part of the library search path that we later use when doing the actual linkage. Is this the case?
